instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power issues
threads.message:
Hi all,

I am trying to troubleshoot power issues with this 2010 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MBP with a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B board.

It has Green light on, no orange.
voltage at main fuse f6905=17.34v bouncing down to 16.94v
Voltage at pin 5 on <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> =3.40v
pin 1 on <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> =3.19v bouncing to =3.26v
pin 4 on <CHIP>U6901</CHIP>=3.33v bouncing to 3.40v 

No signs of liquid damage or previous entry.

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated, as I am very new to this and keen to learn.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power issues
threads.message:
MagSafe light goes to orange only when battery is connected and correctly recognized.
Post <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage w/ and w/o battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power issues
threads.message:
Post voltage and resistance to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and see how <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts.

If machine doesn't start in normal mode, try SMC bypass mode.

Check resistance to ground at 3V42 line (ohm mode); you should get more than 30K.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power issues
threads.message:
Pin 4 =<SIGNAL>SMBUS_BAT_SCL</SIGNAL> = 3.39V
Resistance to ground = 19.8K ohm (after meter settled, I'm guessing it was charging a cap)

Pin 6=<SIGNAL>SMBUS_BAT_SDA</SIGNAL> = 3.39V
Resistance to ground = 86.0 K ohm (after meter settled again)

Sorry, I don't understand the next part:

??????{Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and see how <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts.

If machine doesn't start in normal mode, try SMC bypass mode.}

Pin 2 on <RESISTOR>R5070</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> Resistance to ground = 14.8K ohm

I am very new to this, and this is the first Mac I've tried to diagnose

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power issues
threads.message: Take your tweezers and short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground to start the board. If it doesn?t work, this likely has a dead MCP and can RIP

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power issues
threads.message:
"Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and see how <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts"
Solder a wire to <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (pad 1 of <RESISTOR>R5014</RESISTOR>/15 for example) and touch the ground with it.
Is the same as pressing power button.

"try SMC bypass mode"
Press power button (see above), connect MagSafe and maitain pressing 5-10s...

Post SCL/SDA to ground on diode mode; red probe to ground.

Remove power, wait 20s and check again 3V42 to ground, ohm mode there.
Then invert multimeter probes and check the other value.
None should be less than 30K.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power issues
threads.message:
SCL to ground = 0.533V
SDA to ground = 0.532V
3V42 to ground = 14.85K
3V42 to ground probes reversed = 1.40K

Just to make sure I understand the process here, When I'm doing these tests, the board is removed but the fan is connected.
Should the fan spin when the board is starting up?, if not, how do I know if it is trying to start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Power issues
threads.message: Yes board only plug in the magsafe should get a light on the charger. Then short the power pads (you can google for them) aka <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground with your tweezers, and the fan should spin IF the board is working.
